Company: AIM Advisors, Inc. and AIM Distributors, Inc.
Description: Invesco Funds Group, Inc., AIM Advisors, Inc., and AIM Distributors, Inc. agreed to pay a total of $375 million to settle allegations that they violated federal securities laws by facilitating widespread market timing trading in mutual funds with which each entity was affiliated.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2004-143.htm

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Description: Invesco Funds Group, Inc., AIM Advisors, Inc., and AIM Distributors, Inc. agreed to pay a total of $375 million to settle allegations that they violated federal securities laws by facilitating widespread market timing trading in mutual funds with which each entity was affiliated.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2004-143.htm

Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced a settlement with investment management company OppenheimerFunds Inc. of allegations that its sales and distribution arm made misleading statements about two of its mutual funds struggling in the midst of the credit crisis in late 2008.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/News/PressRelease/Detail/PressRelease/1365171482524

Description: The New York Attorney General and Colorado regulators announced a $125 million settlement -- $50 million in damages and penalties along with $75 million in fee reductions -- with a leading mutual fund company to resolve allegations of unlawful trading through market timing. The settlement damages and penalty portion of the settlement was negotiated together with the SEC, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-aim-advisors-inc-and-aim-distributors-in
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100214200903/http://www.ag.ny.gov/media_center/2004/sep/sep7c_04.html

Description: The New York Attorney General and Colorado regulators announced a $325 million settlement with a leading mutual fund company to resolve allegations of unlawful trading of mutual funds through market timing. The settlement was negotiated together with the SEC, which issued its own announcement; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-invesco-funds-group-inc
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100214200903/http://www.ag.ny.gov/media_center/2004/sep/sep7c_04.html

Description: OppenheimerFunds agreed to pay $67.3 million to resolve an investigation of its management of the state's 529 college savings programs.
Info Source: AG King Announces Settlement with Oppenheimer Funds Regarding Recovery for New Mexico 529 College Savings Account Owners, Targeted News Service, June 16, 2010 (via Nexis).

Description: OppenheimerFunds agreed to pay $20 million to settle allegations of mismanagement, securities fraud, breach of contract, and breach of fiduciary duty in its management of the Oregon 529 College Savings Network.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100514111152/http://www.doj.state.or.us/releases/2009/rel111909.shtml

Description: OppenheimerFunds, Inc. agreed to pay in settlement of allegations it mismanaged funds in the state's college savings plan.
Info Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20100711153424/http://www.illinoisattorneygeneral.gov/pressroom/2009_12/Bright_Start_Settlement_Final.pdf
Notes: Illinois worked with other states, but it appears settlements are separate.

Info Source: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BymCt_FLs-RGM0FxWW9GaE54M2c/view

Description: OppenheimerFunds agreed to pay $394,500 in restitution, a $100,000 fine, and $175,000 in costs in settlement of allegations it operated bulk exchanges of mutual funds with select companies that it failed to disclose in documents, had insufficient records and monitoring, and resulting in dilution of mutual fund returns.
Agency: Washington State Department of Financial Institutions
Info Source: https://dfi.wa.gov/documents/securities-orders/S-04-012-07-CO01.pdf
